Andy

--- In neat@...=
m, Alexandre Devert <marmakoide@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
> 
> =C3=82=C2=A0I put =
my NEAT-based experimental setup online, here : http://www.marmakoide.org/d=
ownload/research/blackbolt-neat-1.0.zip
> The archive is mostly self-contai=
ned, you Python to compile the thing. Documentation included in the package=
. It's a usage of NEAT, not verbatim HyperNEAT : I use input space to compu=
te thickness of beams of a mechanical structure, not the weight for a neuro=
n network. But the principle is the same, NEAT algorithm and CPPN.=C3=82=C2=
=A0Definitely=C3=82=C2=A0compile on Unix-ish systems, should compile on Win=
dows but not tested that. Call mothership if you need support, we're ready =
^^
> 
> Cheers,
> Alex
> 
> ________________________________
>  De=C3=82=C2=
=A0: afcarl2 <afcarl2@...>
> =C3=83=E2=82=AC=C3=82=C2=A0: neat@yahoogroups.=
com

> Objet=C3=82=C2=
=A0: Re: Re : Re : Re : [neat] Any Prior Applications of NEAT In Which The =
Genotype Itself Is The Output?
> 
> 
> =C3=82=C2=A0 
> 
> 
> Alex,
> If an =
individual maps to a point evaluation of the design space, and the local ja=
cobian of the fitness landscape is such that an added local gradient based =
sub-optimization task follows a trajectory resulting in an improved fitness=
 associated w/ an updated individual, would that satisfy the classification=
 requirements associated w/ "implicit evolved embryogeny"? Also, would you =
consider uploading your updated version of Hyperneat used in your study to =
the group file repository?
> Thanks,
> Andy
> 
> --- In neat@...=
m, Alexandre Devert <marmakoide@> wrote:
> >
> > Hi,
> > =C3=83=E2=80=9A=C3=
=82=C2=A0 I'm not 100% sure to get the whole meaning of your question, so I=
 might answer a bit off-target ^^
> > 
> > =C3=83=E2=80=9A=C3=82=C2=A0 In t=
hat paragraph about the taxonomy (end of page 4), I mention "local informat=
ion". It's not a gradient, as in "gradient based optimization", that is, a =
clue on the local geometry of the objective function. By "local information=
", I mean, *any* kind of local feedback of the behavior of the phenotype. I=
f we optimize a plane wing, it could be, say, the local air pressure. If we=
 optimize a heat exchanger, it would be local heath flux. If we optimize a =
water pipe network, it would the local water flux and pressure.
> > 
> > 
>=
 > =C3=83=E2=80=9A=C3=82=C2=A0Then, does this local information feeback tur=
ns "external non-evolved embryogeny" into "implicit evolved embryogeny" ? I=
t's quite a fuzzy territory, if you ask me. Let's say you decode the genoty=
pe as a transformation of an initial phenotype to a final one. You have man=
y many ways to do this, and you can have genotype as a very flexible transf=
ormation (many many development steps, each doing small changes in all poss=
ible ways) or a very inflexible one (1 single very had-hoc transformation s=
tep). So between "external non-evolved embryogeny" and "implicit evolved em=
bryogeny", I believe there is a whole gradient of possibilities rather than=
 a sharp border between the two. Actually, to have a trully "implicit evolv=
ed embryogeny", it would unbounded development. But in practice, allowing a=
 few steps of development brings a lot of flexibility for a genotype, so it=
's a rethoritical remark.
> > 
> > Cheers,
> > 
> > Alex
> > 
> > 
> > ____=

ion.

e@> wrote:<br>

o I might answer a bit off-target ^^<br>
> > <br>
> > =C3=83=E2=
=80=9A=C3=82  In that paragraph about the taxonomy (end of page 4), I =
mention "local information". It's not a gradient, as in "gradient based opt=
imization", that is, a clue on the local geometry of the objective function=
. By "local information", I mean, *any* kind of local feedback of the behav=
ior of the phenotype. If we optimize a plane wing, it could be, say, the lo=
cal air pressure. If we optimize a heat exchanger, it would be local heath =
flux. If we optimize a water pipe network, it would the local water flux an=
d pressure.<br>
> > <br>
> > <br>
> > =C3=83=E2=80=9A=C3=
=82 Then, does this local information feeback turns "external non-evol=
ved embryogeny" into "implicit evolved embryogeny" ? It's quite a fuzzy ter=
ritory, if you ask me. Let's say you decode the genotype as a transformatio=
n of an initial phenotype to a final one. You have many many ways to do thi=
s, and you can have genotype as a very flexible transformation (many many d=
evelopment steps, each doing small changes in all possible ways) or a very =
inflexible one (1 single very had-hoc transformation step). So between "ext=
ernal non-evolved embryogeny" and "implicit evolved embryogeny", I believe =
there is a whole gradient of possibilities rather than a sharp border betwe=
en the two. Actually, to have a trully "implicit evolved embryogeny", it wo=
uld unbounded development. But in practice, allowing a few steps of develop=
ment brings a lot of flexibility for a genotype, so it's a rethoritical rem=
ark.<br>
